content: The Act may be cited as the "Club Drug Anti-Proliferation Act of 2000". The illegal importation of MDMA and PMA has increased in recent years, leading to long-lasting damage to the brain's serotonin system. Club drugs' popularity has resulted in numerous websites providing information on them. Numerous Internet websites provide information on the effects, production, and locations of use of club drugs, targeting primarily college students, young professionals, and young people from middle- to high-income families. Emphasis is needed on penalties associated with club drugs, educating young people on their negative health effects, and training law enforcement on the growing problem. The curr_chunk discusses the need for enforcement agencies to address club drug trafficking, reduce deaths from club drug use, and provide funding for research on prevention, toxic effects, and treatments for club drug abuse. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of researching the effects of club drugs on children and adolescents, translating findings into practical tools, and ensuring effective dissemination. Enhanced punishment for club drug traffickers is emphasized. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend Federal sentencing guidelines for offenses related to certain controlled substances, including club drugs like 3,4-methylenedioxy methamphetamine and paramethoxymethamphetamine. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend Federal sentencing guidelines to increase penalties for offenses involving substances that have a similar effect on the central nervous system as 3,4-methylenedioxy methamphetamine or paramethoxymethamphetamine. The United States Sentencing Commission will take necessary actions to enforce penalties for offenses involving controlled substances, reflecting the need for aggressive law enforcement and addressing the dangers associated with substance abuse and illegal importation. The Sentencing Commission will consider factors such as the increase in illegal importation of controlled substances, the young age of substance users, and any other relevant factors when enforcing penalties for drug offenses. Enhanced punishment for GHB traffickers is addressed in Section 4. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend Federal sentencing guidelines for offenses related to GHB and gamma-butyrolactone trafficking under specified acts. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for offenses involving Schedule I and II depressants to increase penalties and deter these offenses. They will also ensure that offenses with significant quantities of these substances receive longer prison terms and consider the dangers associated with their use. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for offenses involving controlled substances to increase penalties and deter illegal activity. This includes addressing the dangers of substance abuse, public safety threats, and the rise in illegal manufacturing of these substances. Additionally, there is a prohibition on distributing information related to the manufacture or acquisition of controlled substances. Section 403 of the Controlled Substances Act prohibits the distribution of information relating to the manufacture or acquisition of controlled substances. It is unlawful to teach or demonstrate the manufacture of a controlled substance or distribute information about it with the intent for illegal use. The Controlled Substances Act prohibits distributing information on manufacturing controlled substances, with penalties including fines and up to 10 years in prison for violations. SEC. 7 mandates placing antidrug messages on federal government websites within 90 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 8 expands prevention efforts for club drug abuse through grants. The Administrator may provide grants and agreements to public and nonprofit entities for school-based and community-based programs addressing the dangers of specific drugs through effective and science-based methods. Amounts received must be used for the designated programs. Amounts provided under this section can be used for school-based and community-based prevention programs targeting districts with high rates of abuse of specific drugs and populations most at risk. The funding provided can be used for prevention activities targeting populations at risk for abuse of specific drugs, training law enforcement officials, health professionals, and parents on signs of addiction, and planning educational activities for prevention. Grants under this subsection prioritize rural and urban areas with high rates of abuse and addiction to specific drugs, allocating not less than $500,000 each fiscal year for prevention programs. The Administrator, in consultation with other Federal agencies, will use the available funds to support and conduct analyses and evaluations of prevention programs for specific drugs. An annual report on the results will be submitted to relevant Senate and House committees. The Director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy will ensure that the national media campaign addresses the reduction and prevention of abuse of specific drugs among young people in the United States. Authorization is provided for appropriations to carry out this subsection.
